sections.procedure:
1.  The case originated in an application (no. 66610/10) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Russian national, Mr Yevgeniy Nikolayevich Zakharov (“the applicant”) on 16 October 2010.
2.  The applicant was granted leave to present his own case under Rule 36 § 2 in fine of the Rules of Court. The Russian Government (“the Government”) were represented by Mr G. Matyushkin, Representative of the Russian Federation to the European Court of Human Rights.
3.  The applicant alleged, in particular, that his right to respect for his home had been violated.
4.  On 5 November 2015 the complaint concerning the alleged violation of the applicant’s right to respect for his home was communicated to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
sections.circumstances:
5.  The applicant was born in 1944 and lives in Kaliningrad.
6.  Until 1999 the applicant was married to Z. and was living with her in a state-owned flat which had been provided to Z.’s parents. The applicant was registered as living in that flat.
7.  In 1999 the applicant and Z. divorced and the applicant moved in with his new partner, B. At that time he did not apply for deregistration from the flat which he had occupied with his former wife. Later Z. privatised that flat, and the applicant lost occupational right to it.
8.  B. occupied a room in a three-room communal flat under a social tenancy agreement. The other two rooms were occupied by her neighbours. The applicant and B. lived together in that room for the following ten years. They never married and the applicant was not registered as living in the room.
9.  In May 2009 B. died and her neighbours locked the applicant out of the flat. The local housing authority informed the applicant that he had to vacate the room, since he had no legal right to occupy it.
10.  On 28 September 2009 the applicant instituted court proceedings against the local administration, seeking recognition of his right to occupy the room as B.’s family member. He submitted that he and B. had been living in the room as husband and wife since 1988, but that after her death her neighbours had locked him out of the room. He considered that despite the fact that he had not been married to B. and had not been registered as living in the room, he should be regarded as a member of her family who had acquired the right to occupy her room. In particular, he raised the following arguments:
-  he had shared a common household with B.;
-  he had paid for the maintenance of the room;
-  he had assumed the cost of B.’s burial;
-  he had no other housing: he could not return to the flat of his former wife Z. since she had become the owner of that flat and lived there with her new family;
-  on 8 September 2009 he had asked the authorities to deregister him from the flat of his former wife Z.;
-  since his eviction, he had been obliged to live in the school in which he was working as a night watchman.
11.  The local administration submitted that the applicant had not been registered as living in B.’s room, he was not a member of B.’s family and, therefore, he had not acquired any right to occupy her room.
12.  B.’s neighbours were invited to participate in the proceedings as third parties. They confirmed that between 1999 and 2009 the applicant had lived in the room with B. and had provided her with financial support. However, they considered that B.’s room should be allocated to them and not to the applicant, since there were six of them living in two rooms and they needed to upgrade their living conditions.
13.  On 6 May 2010 the Leninskiy District Court (“the District Court”) of Kaliningrad granted the applicant’s claim with reference to Articles 69 and 70 of the Housing Code (see Relevant domestic law and practice below). The District Court established, in particular, that between 1999 and 2009 the applicant had cohabited with B. in the room in question, had shared a common household with her and had been removed from the register at his previous place of residence. The District Court considered that the above circumstances should be regarded as exceptional within the meaning of Article 69 of the Housing Code and that the applicant should therefore be regarded as a member of B.’s family who had acquired the right to reside in the room previously occupied by her.
14.  The local administration did not appeal against the judgment of 6 May 2010.
15.  The third parties appealed against that judgment to the Kaliningrad Regional Court (“the Regional Court”). They submitted that B. had on several occasions chased the applicant away. She had not applied to the authorities with a request to register him as living in her room, and had not asked that his name be added to the social tenancy agreement as a member of her family. The applicant had not paid any utility charges for the room and had been registered as living elsewhere until B.’s death.
16.  On 22 September 2010 the Regional Court quashed the judgment of 6 May 2010 and dismissed the applicant’s claims. The relevant part of the decision of 22 September 2010 reads as follows:
“When granting the claims of Mr Zakharov Ye. N. [the applicant], the court [the District Court] proceeded from the premise that there existed exceptional circumstances allowing it to recognise him as a member of Ms Brazhnikova’s [B.’s] family in accordance with Article 69 § 1 of the Housing Code.
The Civil Chamber [of the Kaliningrad Regional Court] cannot agree with such a decision.
The court [the District Court] established on the basis of the plaintiff’s and witnesses’ submissions that the plaintiff had lived together with Ms Brazhnikova L.P. [B.] since 1999 and had shared a common household with her.
The above circumstances are not in themselves exceptional, in particular given that no irrefutable evidence had been submitted to the court to prove that Ms Brazhnikova L. P. had let Mr Zakharov live in the flat as a family member rather than as a temporary resident. Throughout the period in which he lived together with Ms Brazhnikova L.P., the plaintiff had been registered as living in house no. 6, Pionerskaya street in the village of Aleksandrovka in the Zelenogradskiy district. He asked to be removed from the register on 8 September 2009 after the death of Ms Brazhnikova and just before applying to the court.
Therefore, the circumstances of the case do not allow the court to recognise Mr Zakharov Ye. N. as a family member of the social tenant Ms Brazhnikova L.P. as well as acknowledging his right to occupy the flat in question. It follows that the court judgment should be quashed and a new decision should be taken dismissing those claims.”
17.  On 3 March 2011 a judge of the Supreme Court of Russia (“the Supreme Court”) refused to refer the applicant’s application for supervisory review of the decision of 22 September 2010 to the Civil Chamber of the Supreme Court for examination, finding no grounds for such review and relying on the principle of legal certainty.
II.  RELEVANT DOMESTIC LAW AND PRACTICE
A.  Constitution of the Russian Federation
18.  Article 40 of the Constitution provides that everyone has the right to a home. Nobody may be arbitrarily deprived of his or her home.
B.  Housing Code of the Russian Federation of 29 December 2004, in force since 1 March 2005
19.  Article 69 § 1 of the Code provides that members of a tenant’s family include his or her spouse, children and parents if they live together with the tenant. Other relatives and disabled dependants may be recognised as the tenant’s family if the tenant accommodates them as such and if they share a common household with the tenant. In exceptional cases a court may recognise other persons as members of the tenant’s family.
20.  Article 70 provides that a tenant is entitled to share his home with his spouse, children and parents or other persons living with him as members of his family.
C.  Case-law of the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation
21.  In its Ruling No. 8 of 31 October 1995 on certain questions relating to the application by courts of the Constitution of the Russian Federation in the administration of justice, the Supreme Court of Russia held as follows (paragraph 13):
“When adjudicating on housing disputes, the courts shall take into account that the Constitution of the Russian Federation provides everyone who is legally present on the territory of the Russian Federation with the right to travel freely and freely to choose their place of temporary or permanent residence. It also provides everyone with the right to a home (Article 27 § 1, Article 40 § 1[of the Constitution]).
Having regard to these provisions of the Constitution, it should be borne in mind that the absence of propiska or registration, which has replaced propiska , cannot in itself serve as grounds for restricting people’s rights and freedoms, including the right to home. When adjudicating on claims concerning the recognition of the right to use housing premises, it should be taken into account that information about the existence or absence of propiska (registration) is only one item of evidence to be examined in order to see whether there was an agreement between the tenant (owner) of the premises, or his family members allowing the person to live in their housing and under which conditions ...”
22.  In its Ruling No. 14 of 2 July 2009 on certain questions arising in judicial practice with regard to the application of the Housing Code of the Russian Federation, the Supreme Court of Russia held as follows (paragraph 25):
“...
In accordance with Article 69 § 1 of the Housing Code, in exceptional cases a court may recognise other persons [apart from the spouse, children or parents of the tenant living with him and other close relatives and dependants] as the tenant’s family members. In taking a decision regarding the possibility of recognising other persons as the tenant’s family members (for example, a person who is living together with the tenant without being married), the court should find out whether those persons were let in as the tenant’s family member or in some other capacity, whether they shared a common household with the tenant, for how long they were living in the housing in question and whether they had a right to other housing and had not lost that right.”

events.source_text: A. Constitution of the Russian Federation 18. Article 40 of the Constitution provides that everyone has the right to a home. Nobody may be arbitrarily deprived of his or her home.
events.event_what: right to a home

events.source_text: B. Housing Code of the Russian Federation of 29 December 2004, in force since 1 March 2005 19. Article 69 § 1 of the Code provides that members of a tenant’s family include his or her spouse, children and parents if they live together with the tenant. Other relatives and disabled dependants may be recognised as the tenant’s family if the tenant accommodates them as such and if they share a common household with the tenant. In exceptional cases a court may recognise other persons as members of the tenant’s family.
events.event_what: recognise other persons as the tenant’s family

events.source_text: 21. In its Ruling No. 8 of 31 October 1995 on certain questions relating to the application by courts of the Constitution of the Russian Federation in the administration of justice, the Supreme Court of Russia held as follows (paragraph 13): “When adjudicating on housing disputes, the courts shall take into account that the Constitution of the Russian Federation provides everyone who is legally present on the territory of the Russian Federation with the right to travel freely and freely to choose their place of temporary or permanent residence. It also provides everyone with the right to a home (Article 27 § 1, Article 40 § 1[of the Constitution]). Having regard to these provisions of the Constitution, it should be borne in mind that the absence of propiska or registration, which has replaced propiska , cannot in itself serve as grounds for restricting people’s rights and freedoms, including the right to home. When adjudicating on claims concerning the recognition of the right to use housing premises, it should be taken into account that information about the existence or absence of propiska (registration) is only one item of evidence to be examined in order to see whether there was an agreement between the tenant (owner) of the premises, or his family members allowing the person to live in their housing and under which conditions ...”, 22. In its Ruling No. 14 of 2 July 2009 on certain questions arising in judicial practice with regard to the application of the Housing Code of the Russian Federation, the Supreme Court of Russia held as follows (paragraph 25): “... In accordance with Article 69 § 1 of the Housing Code, in exceptional cases a court may recognise other persons [apart from the spouse, children or parents of the tenant living with him and other close relatives and dependants] as the tenant’s family members. In taking a decision regarding the possibility of recognising other persons as the tenant’s family members (for example, a person who is living together with the tenant without being married), the court should find out whether those persons were let in as the tenant’s family member or in some other capacity, whether they shared a common household with the tenant, for how long they were living in the housing in question and whether they had a right to other housing and had not lost that right.”
events.event_what: held as follows

events.source_text: The case originated in an application (no. 66610/10) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Russian national, Mr Yevgeniy Nikolayevich Zakharov (“the applicant”) on 16 October 2010.
events.event_what: lodged

events.source_text: The applicant was granted leave to present his own case under Rule 36 § 2 in fine of the Rules of Court.
events.event_what: granted

events.source_text: The applicant alleged, in particular, that his right to respect for his home had been violated.
events.event_what: alleged

events.source_text: On 5 November 2015 the complaint concerning the alleged violation of the applicant’s right to respect for his home was communicated to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
events.event_what: communicated

events.source_text: The applicant was born in 1944 and lives in Kaliningrad.
events.event_what: was born

events.source_text: Until 1999 the applicant was married to Z. and was living with her in a state-owned flat which had been provided to Z.’s parents.
events.event_what: was

events.source_text: In 1999 the applicant and Z. divorced and the applicant moved in with his new partner, B.
events.event_what: divorced

events.source_text: At that time he did not apply for deregistration from the flat which he had occupied with his former wife.
events.event_what: did not apply

events.source_text: Later Z. privatised that flat, and the applicant lost occupational right to it.
events.event_what: privatised

events.source_text: B. occupied a room in a three-room communal flat under a social tenancy agreement.
events.event_what: occupied

events.source_text: In May 2009 B. died and her neighbours locked the applicant out of the flat.
events.event_what: died

events.source_text: The local housing authority informed the applicant that he had to vacate the room, since he had no legal right to occupy it.
events.event_what: informed

events.source_text: On 28 September 2009 the applicant instituted court proceedings against the local administration, seeking recognition of his right to occupy the room as B.’s family member.
events.event_what: instituted

events.source_text: The local administration submitted that the applicant had not been registered as living in B.’s room, he was not a member of B.’s family and, therefore, he had not acquired any right to occupy her room.
events.event_what: submitted

events.source_text: B.’s neighbours were invited to participate in the proceedings as third parties.
events.event_what: were invited

events.source_text: On 6 May 2010 the Leninskiy District Court (“the District Court”) granted the applicant’s claim with reference to Articles 69 and 70 of the Housing Code.
events.event_what: granted

events.source_text: The local administration did not appeal against the judgment of 6 May 2010.
events.event_what: did not appeal

events.source_text: The third parties appealed against that judgment to the Kaliningrad Regional Court (“the Regional Court”).
events.event_what: appealed

events.source_text: On 22 September 2010 the Regional Court quashed the judgment of 6 May 2010 and dismissed the applicant’s claims.
events.event_what: quashed

events.source_text: On 3 March 2011 a judge of the Supreme Court of Russia (“the Supreme Court”) refused to refer the applicant’s application for supervisory review of the decision of 22 September 2010 to the Civil Chamber of the Supreme Court for examination, finding no grounds for such review and relying on the principle of legal certainty.
events.event_who: judge of the Supreme Court of Russia
events.event_what: refused

events.source_text: The case originated in an application (no. 66610/10) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Russian national, Mr Yevgeniy Nikolayevich Zakharov (“the applicant”) on 16 October 2010.
events.event_what: a violation of Article 8 of the Convention was found by the Court.

events.source_text: The case originated in an application (no. 66610/10) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms ("the Convention") by a Russian national, Mr Yevgeniy Nikolayevich Zakharov ("the applicant") on 16 October 2010.
events.event_what: lodged an application

events.source_text: The applicant was granted leave to present his own case under Rule 36 § 2 in fine of the Rules of Court.
events.event_what: present his own case

events.source_text: The Russian Government ("the Government") were represented by Mr G. Matyushkin, Representative of the Russian Federation to the European Court of Human Rights.
events.event_what: by Mr G. Matyushkin

events.source_text: The applicant alleged, in particular, that his right to respect for his home had been violated.
events.event: The applicant claimed violation of rights
events.event_what: his right to respect for his home

events.source_text: On 5 November 2015 the complaint concerning the alleged violation of the applicant’s right to respect for his home was communicated to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
events.event_what: was communicated to the Government

events.source_text: The applicant was born in 1944 and lives in Kaliningrad.
events.event_what: was born in 1944 and lives in Kaliningrad

events.source_text: Until 1999 the applicant was married to Z. and was living with her in a state-owned flat which had been provided to Z.’s parents.
events.event: The applicant lived with his wife
events.event_what: with his wife in a state-owned flat

events.source_text: In 1999 the applicant and Z. divorced and the applicant moved in with his new partner, B.
events.event: The applicant moved in with a new partner
events.event_what: with his new partner, B.

events.source_text: At that time he did not apply for deregistration from the flat which he had occupied with his former wife.
events.event: The applicant did not apply for deregistration
events.event_what: from the flat which he had occupied with his former wife

events.source_text: Later Z. privatised that flat, and the applicant lost occupational right to it.
events.event_what: to the flat

events.source_text: B. occupied a room in a three-room communal flat under a social tenancy agreement.
events.event_what: in a three-room communal flat under a social tenancy agreement

events.source_text: The other two rooms were occupied by her neighbours.
events.event: Her neighbours occupied the other rooms
events.event_what: in the three-room communal flat

events.source_text: The applicant and B. lived together in that room for the following ten years.
events.event: The applicant and B. lived together
events.event_what: in that room for ten years

events.source_text: They never married and the applicant was not registered as living in the room.
events.event: The applicant was not registered as living in the room
events.event_what: in the room

events.source_text: In May 2009 B. died and her neighbours locked the applicant out of the flat.
events.event: B. died and the applicant was locked out
events.event_what: of the flat

events.source_text: The local housing authority informed the applicant that he had to vacate the room, since he had no legal right to occupy it.
events.event: The local housing authority informed the applicant
events.event_what: that he had to vacate the room

events.source_text: On 28 September 2009 the applicant instituted court proceedings against the local administration, seeking recognition of his right to occupy the room as B.’s family member.
events.event_what: against the local administration, seeking recognition of his right to occupy the room as B.’s family member.

events.source_text: He submitted that he and B. had been living in the room as husband and wife since 1988, but that after her death her neighbours had locked him out of the room.
events.event: The applicant submitted that he and B. lived together
events.event_what: as husband and wife

events.source_text: He considered that despite the fact that he had not been married to B. and had not been registered as living in the room, he should be regarded as a member of her family who had acquired the right to occupy her room.
events.event: The applicant considered that he should be regarded
events.event_what: as a member of her family who had acquired the right to occupy her room

events.source_text: In particular, he raised the following arguments:
events.event: The applicant raised the following arguments

events.source_text: He had shared a common household with B.
events.event: The applicant shared a common household with B.

events.source_text: He had paid for the maintenance of the room.
events.event: The applicant paid for the maintenance of the room

events.source_text: He had assumed the cost of B.’s burial.
events.event: The applicant assumed the cost of B.’s burial

events.source_text: He had no other housing: he could not return to the flat of his former wife Z. since she had become the owner of that flat and lived there with her new family.
events.event: The applicant had no other housing
events.event_what: he could not return to the flat of his former wife Z.

events.source_text: On 8 September 2009 he had asked the authorities to deregister him from the flat of his former wife Z.
events.event: The applicant asked the authorities to deregister
events.event_what: from the flat of his former wife Z.

events.source_text: Since his eviction, he had been obliged to live in the school in which he was working as a night watchman.
events.event: The applicant had been obliged to live
events.event_what: in the school where he worked as a night watchman

events.source_text: B.’s neighbours were invited to participate in the proceedings as third parties.
events.event: B.’s neighbours were invited to participate
events.event_what: in the proceedings as third parties

events.source_text: They confirmed that between 1999 and 2009 the applicant had lived in the room with B. and had provided her with financial support.
events.event: B.’s neighbours confirmed that the applicant had lived
events.event_what: in the room with B. and provided her with financial support

events.source_text: However, they considered that B.’s room should be allocated to them and not to the applicant, since there were six of them living in two rooms and they needed to upgrade their living conditions.
events.event: B.’s neighbours considered that B.’s room should be allocated
events.event_what: to them and not to the applicant

events.source_text: On 6 May 2010 the Leninskiy District Court ("the District Court") of Kaliningrad granted the applicant’s claim with reference to Articles 69 and 70 of the Housing Code (see Relevant domestic law and practice below).
events.event: The District Court granted the applicant's claim
events.event_what: with reference to Articles 69 and 70 of the Housing Code

events.source_text: The District Court established, in particular, that between 1999 and 2009 the applicant had cohabited with B. in the room in question, had shared a common household with her and had been removed from the register at his previous place of residence.
events.event_what: that the applicant had cohabited with B. in the room, shared a common household with her and was removed from the register at his previous place of residence.

events.source_text: The District Court considered that the above circumstances should be regarded as exceptional within the meaning of Article 69 of the Housing Code and that the applicant should therefore be regarded as a member of B.’s family who had acquired the right to reside in the room previously occupied by her.
events.event_what: that the above circumstances should be regarded as exceptional and that the applicant should be regarded as a member of B.’s family who had acquired the right to reside in the room previously occupied by her.

events.source_text: The local administration did not appeal against the judgment of 6 May 2010.
events.event: The local administration did not appeal

events.source_text: The third parties appealed against that judgment to the Kaliningrad Regional Court ("the Regional Court").
events.event: The third parties appealed against the judgment

events.source_text: They submitted that B. had on several occasions chased the applicant away.
events.event: The third parties submitted that B. had chased the applicant away

events.source_text: She had not applied to the authorities with a request to register him as living in her room, and had not asked that his name be added to the social tenancy agreement as a member of her family.
events.event: B. did not apply or ask
events.event_what: to register him as living in her room or to add his name to the social tenancy agreement as a member of her family

events.source_text: The applicant had not paid any utility charges for the room and had been registered as living elsewhere until B.’s death.
events.event: The applicant had not paid any utility charges
events.event_what: for the room and was registered as living elsewhere

events.source_text: On 22 September 2010 the Regional Court quashed the judgment of 6 May 2010 and dismissed the applicant’s claims.
events.event: The Regional Court quashed the judgment
events.event_what: and dismissed the applicant’s claims

events.source_text: The relevant part of the decision of 22 September 2010 reads as follows:
events.event: The relevant part of the decision reads as follows

events.source_text: When granting the claims of Mr Zakharov Ye. N. [the applicant], the court [the District Court] proceeded from the premise that there existed exceptional circumstances allowing it to recognise him as a member of Ms Brazhnikova’s [B.] family in accordance with Article 69 § 1 of the Housing Code.
events.event: The District Court proceeded from the premise
events.event_what: that there existed exceptional circumstances allowing it to recognise the applicant as a member of B.’s family in accordance with Article 69 § 1 of the Housing Code.

events.source_text: The Civil Chamber [of the Kaliningrad Regional Court] cannot agree with such a decision.
events.event: The Civil Chamber cannot agree with the decision

events.source_text: The court [the District Court] established on the basis of the plaintiff’s and witnesses’ submissions that the plaintiff had lived together with Ms Brazhnikova L.P. [B.] since 1999 and had shared a common household with her.
events.event_what: that the applicant had lived together with B. and shared a common household with her

events.source_text: The above circumstances are not in themselves exceptional, in particular given that no irrefutable evidence had been submitted to the court to prove that Ms Brazhnikova L. P. had let Mr Zakharov live in the flat as a family member rather than as a temporary resident.
events.event_what: that the above circumstances are not in themselves exceptional and that no irrefutable evidence had been submitted to prove that B. let Mr Zakharov live in the flat as a family member rather than as a temporary resident.

events.source_text: Throughout the period in which he lived together with Ms Brazhnikova L.P., the plaintiff had been registered as living in house no. 6, Pionerskaya street in the village of Aleksandrovka in the Zelenogradskiy district.
events.event_when: Throughout the period he lived together with B.
events.event_what: as living in house no. 6, Pionerskaya street in the village of Aleksandrovka in the Zelenogradskiy district

events.source_text: He asked to be removed from the register on 8 September 2009 after the death of Ms Brazhnikova and just before applying to the court.
events.event: The applicant asked to be removed from the register
events.event_when: on 8 September 2009 after the death of B. and just before applying to the court

events.source_text: Therefore, the circumstances of the case do not allow the court to recognise Mr Zakharov Ye. N. as a family member of the social tenant Ms Brazhnikova L.P.
events.event: The court does not recognise the applicant as a family member
events.event_what: of the social tenant B.

events.source_text: It follows that the court judgment should be quashed and a new decision should be taken dismissing those claims.
events.event: The court judgment should be quashed
events.event_what: and a new decision should be taken dismissing the applicant’s claims

events.source_text: On 3 March 2011 a judge of the Supreme Court of Russia ("the Supreme Court") refused to refer the applicant’s application for supervisory review of the decision of 22 September 2010 to the Civil Chamber of the Supreme Court for examination, finding no grounds for such review and relying on the principle of legal certainty.
events.event: The judge of the Supreme Court refused
events.event_who: The judge of the Supreme Court
events.event_what: to refer the applicant’s application for supervisory review to the Civil Chamber of the Supreme Court for examination, finding no grounds for such review and relying on the principle of legal certainty.

events.source_text: II.  RELEVANT DOMESTIC LAW AND PRACTICE
events.event: Relevant domestic law and practice is provided

events.source_text: A.  Constitution of the Russian Federation
events.event: The Constitution of the Russian Federation is provided

events.source_text: 18.  Article 40 of the Constitution provides that everyone has the right to a home. Nobody may be arbitrarily deprived of his or her home.
events.event_what: that everyone has the right to a home and nobody may be arbitrarily deprived of his or her home

events.source_text: B.  Housing Code of the Russian Federation of 29 December 2004, in force since 1 March 2005
events.event: The Housing Code of the Russian Federation is provided

events.source_text: 19.  Article 69 § 1 of the Code provides that members of a tenant’s family include his or her spouse, children and parents if they live together with the tenant.
events.event_what: that members of a tenant’s family include his or her spouse, children and parents if they live together with the tenant

events.source_text: 20.  Article 70 provides that a tenant is entitled to share his home with his spouse, children and parents or other persons living with him as members of his family.
events.event_what: that a tenant is entitled to share his home with his spouse, children and parents or other persons living with him as members of his family

events.source_text: C.  Case-law of the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation
events.event: The case-law of the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation is provided

events.source_text: 21.  In its Ruling No. 8 of 31 October 1995 on certain questions relating to the application by courts of the Constitution of the Russian Federation in the administration of justice, the Supreme Court of Russia held as follows (paragraph 13):
events.event: The Supreme Court of Russia held as follows in its Ruling No. 8
events.event_what: on certain questions relating to the application by courts of the Constitution of the Russian Federation in the administration of justice

events.source_text: 22.  In its Ruling No. 14 of 2 July 2009 on certain questions arising in judicial practice with regard to the application of the Housing Code of the Russian Federation, the Supreme Court of Russia held as follows (paragraph 25):
events.event: The Supreme Court of Russia held as follows in its Ruling No. 14
events.event_what: on certain questions arising in judicial practice with regard to the application of the Housing Code of the Russian Federation

events.source_text: FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY,
1.   Declares the application admissible;
2.   Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;
events.event: The Court holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention

events.source_text: 3.   Holds (a)  that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months of the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 § 2 of the Convention, EUR 5,000 (five thousand euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of nonpecuniary damage, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement;
events.event: The Court holds that the respondent State is to pay the applicant
events.event_what: EUR 5,000 plus any tax in respect of nonpecuniary damage

events.source_text: 3.   Holds (b)  that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement, simple interest shall be payable on the above amount at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period, plus three percentage points.
events.event: The Court holds that simple interest shall be payable
events.event_what: on the above amount at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period, plus three percentage points

events.source_text: The case originated in an application (no. 66610/10) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Russian national, Mr Yevgeniy Nikolayevich Zakharov (“the applicant”) on 16 October 2010.
events.event_what: lodged an application

events.source_text: The applicant alleged, in particular, that his right to respect for his home had been violated.
events.event_what: alleged that his right to respect for his home had been violated

events.source_text: On 5 November 2015 the complaint concerning the alleged violation of the applicant’s right to respect for his home was communicated to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
events.event_who: The European Court of Human Rights
events.event_what: communicated the complaint to the Government and declared the remainder of the application inadmissible

events.source_text: On 28 September 2009 the applicant instituted court proceedings against the local administration, seeking recognition of his right to occupy the room as B.’s family member.
events.event_what: instituted court proceedings against the local administration, seeking recognition of his right to occupy the room as B.’s family member

events.source_text: On 6 May 2010 the Leninskiy District Court (“the District Court”) of Kaliningrad granted the applicant’s claim with reference to Articles 69 and 70 of the Housing Code (see Relevant domestic law and practice below).
events.event_what: granted the applicant’s claim with reference to Articles 69 and 70 of the Housing Code

events.source_text: On 22 September 2010 the Regional Court quashed the judgment of 6 May 2010 and dismissed the applicant’s claims.
events.event_what: quashed the judgment of 6 May 2010 and dismissed the applicant’s claims

events.source_text: On 3 March 2011 a judge of the Supreme Court of Russia (“the Supreme Court”) refused to refer the applicant’s application for supervisory review of the decision of 22 September 2010 to the Civil Chamber of the Supreme Court for examination, finding no grounds for such review and relying on the principle of legal certainty.
events.event: Supervisory review refusal by Supreme Court
events.event_who: A judge of the Supreme Court of Russia
events.event_what: refused to refer the applicant’s application for supervisory review, finding no grounds for such review and relying on the principle of legal certainty

events.source_text: The Court declares the application admissible; holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention; holds that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months of the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 § 2 of the Convention, EUR 5,000 (five thousand euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of nonpecuniary damage, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement; and that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement, simple interest shall be payable on the above amount at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period, plus three percentage points.
events.event_who: The European Court of Human Rights
events.event_what: declared the application admissible; held that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention; ordered payment of EUR 5,000 for nonpecuniary damage and simple interest

events.event_what: lodged an application

events.source_text: The applicant was granted leave to present his own case under Rule 36 µ2 in fine of the Rules of Court. The Russian Government ('the Government') were represented by Mr G. Matyushkin, Representative of the Russian Federation to the European Court of Human Rights.
events.event_what: granted leave to present his own case

events.source_text: The applicant alleged, in particular, that his right to respect for his home had been violated.

events.source_text: On 5 November 2015 the complaint concerning the alleged violation of the applicant's right to respect for his home was communicated to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 µ3 of the Rules of Court.
events.event_what: communication of complaint and declaration of remainder of application as inadmissible

events.source_text: The applicant was born in 1944 and lives in Kaliningrad.
events.event_what: information about the applicant

events.source_text: Until 1999 the applicant was married to Z. and was living with her in a state-owned flat which had been provided to Z.'s parents. The applicant was registered as living in that flat.
events.event_what: living arrangement details

events.source_text: In 1999 the applicant and Z. divorced and the applicant moved in with his new partner, B. At that time he did not apply for deregistration from the flat which he had occupied with his former wife.
events.event_what: divorce and moving in with a new partner

events.source_text: Later Z. privatised that flat, and the applicant lost occupational right to it.
events.event_what: loss of occupancy rights due to privatization

events.source_text: B. occupied a room in a three-room communal flat under a social tenancy agreement. The other two rooms were occupied by her neighbours. The applicant and B. lived together in that room for the following ten years. They never married and the applicant was not registered as living in the room.
events.event_what: living arrangement details with B.

events.source_text: In May 2009 B. died and her neighbours locked the applicant out of the flat. The local housing authority informed the applicant that he had to vacate the room, since he had no legal right to occupy it.
events.event_what: death of B. and subsequent lockout

events.source_text: On 28 September 2009 the applicant instituted court proceedings against the local administration, seeking recognition of his right to occupy the room as B.'s family member.
events.event_what: initiation of court proceedings

events.source_text: He submitted that he and B. had been living in the room as husband and wife since 1988, but that after her death her neighbours had locked him out of the room.
events.event_what: assertion of living arrangement with B.

events.source_text: He considered that despite the fact that he had not been married to B. and had not been registered as living in the room, he should be regarded as a member of her family who had acquired the right to occupy her room.
events.event_what: assertion of familial status and rights acquisition

events.source_text: In particular, he raised the following arguments:
events.event_what: presentation of arguments in court

events.source_text: The local administration submitted that the applicant had not been registered as living in B.'s room, he was not a member of B.'s family and, therefore, he had not acquired any right to occupy her room.
events.event_what: submission by local administration

events.source_text: B.'s neighbours were invited to participate in the proceedings as third parties. They confirmed that between 1999 and 2009 the applicant had lived together with B. and had provided her with financial support.
events.event_what: participation of neighbors in proceedings and confirmation of living arrangement

events.source_text: On 6 May 2010 the Leninskiy District Court ('the District Court') of Kaliningrad granted the applicant's claim with reference to Articles 69 and 70 of the Housing Code (see Relevant domestic law and practice below).
events.event_what: granting of applicant's claim

events.source_text: The District Court established, in particular, that between 1999 and 2009 the applicant had cohabited with B. in the room in question, had shared a common household with her and had been removed from the register at his previous place of residence.
events.event_what: court findings on living arrangement

events.source_text: The District Court considered that the above circumstances should be regarded as exceptional within the meaning of Article 69 of the Housing Code and that the applicant should therefore be regarded as a member of B.'s family who had acquired the right to reside in the room previously occupied by her.
events.event_what: court decision on exceptional circumstances

events.source_text: The local administration did not appeal against the judgment of 6 May 2010.
events.event_what: non-appeal by local administration

events.source_text: The third parties appealed against that judgment to the Kaliningrad Regional Court ('the Regional Court'). They submitted that B. had on several occasions chased the applicant away.
events.event_what: appeal of court decision and submission of evidence

events.source_text: On 22 September 2010 the Regional Court quashed the judgment of 6 May 2010 and dismissed the applicant's claims.
events.event_what: quashing of previous court decision and dismissal of claims

events.source_text: The relevant part of the decision of 22 September 2010 reads as follows:
events.event_what: summary of court decision

events.source_text: When adjudicating on housing disputes, the courts shall take into account that the Constitution of the Russian Federation provides everyone who is legally present on the territory of the Russian Federation with the right to travel freely and freely to choose their place of temporary or permanent residence.
events.event_what: court consideration of constitutional rights

events.source_text: On 3 March 2011 a judge of the Supreme Court of Russia ('the Supreme Court') refused to refer the applicant's application for supervisory review of the decision of 22 September 2010 to the Civil Chamber of the Supreme Court for examination, finding no grounds for such review and relying on the principle of legal certainty.
events.event_what: refusal to refer application for supervisory review
